dialogues.speaker: -INT. WAGON
dialogues.text: The black screen is, in fact, the canvas side of a wagon. inside, hiding, are two boys. They are: JOAQUIN MURIETTA, ten years old, on his way to manhood. A older brother, gentle with and protective of: ALEJANDRO MURIETTA, eight. Despite his age, Alejandro is natural leader of the two, although neither knows it. Alejandro moves over, so he peeks out one eye hole. Joaqu through the other.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT THEY SEE
dialogues.text: THE TOWN SQUARE. Whitewashed walls and terra cotta, the S leaching color, creating an almost black-and-white look. with people, milling restlessly, on the edge of where a c becomes a mob. Order is kept by dozens of SOLDIERS, standing sternly at They keep a perimeter in the form a large semi-circle in the VICEROY'S BUILDING. A six-man FIRING SQUAD sets up. T bound PRISONERS await their fate.

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: He’s not going to come.

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: Should we move closer? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly light spills across the two boys.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERTAKER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hooligans! What do you think you're doing? Get out of here! An UNDERTAKER glares in at them, holding up a flap of can wears a black suit as severe as his expression. It's his evidenced by the three empty coffins inside.

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: We should move closer! He slices the canvas, and the two dive out into the squar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys scramble around and among the legs of onlookers, closer to the semi-circle.

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: I don't see him.

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: He's got to come. He’s very brave. On all fours, they slip past a group of UNIFORMED SOLDIER

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: Yes, but he’s also very smart. [The boys crawl past a MAN in ROUGH HOODED CLOAK, his san visible -- He reaches out and grabs them (gently) by the ears. It is FELIPE, an out-of-place scowl on his round, jovial face.

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: (horrified) Fray Felipe!

dialogues.speaker: FELIPE
dialogues.text: Do you suppose you're parents -- God- rest-their-souls -- would approve of you two being here? (leans closer; worried) There's going to be trouble. Get back to the mission -- now! He gives them a little push. Abashed, they move away, awa Felipe watching them. But as soon as he turns away -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alejandro grabs Joaquin, yanks him down. Back on all four leading, they crawl back through the crowd. Suddenly, Ale cut off, bumping into the knees of a MAN in a ROUGH HOODE Sure he's caught, he looks down --] Beneath the monk's robe are SHINY BLACK BOOTS WITH SILVER And the SILVER TIP of a SCABBARD. ?Alejandro's eyes go wide. He looks up -- ANGLE - LOOKING UP: Beneath the monk's hood, a mask, a da mustache, the flash of a smile. It's ZORRO. He puts a fin his lips: 'Shhh.' Alejandro wheels, scrambles back to Joaquin.

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: Joaquin! He's here! He's here!

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: Zorro's here?

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: (a finger to his lips, a la Zorro) SHHHH! He's right over there -- [He points -- ?The monk's robe lies discarded on the ground. ] Alejandro looks around in wonder, amazed at the disappear Joaquin grabs his hand, heads for a ladder.

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: C'mon! Alejandro is dragged along; he barely avoids running into DON LUIZ, an older man, tall and thin, with an elegant go pushes through the crowd, reaches the entrance to the Vic Building. Soldiers meet him with a challenge.

dialogues.speaker: DON LUIZ
dialogues.text: Don Luiz. The Viceroy sent for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don Luiz moves down a hallway, his face pale, eyes taking activity. He dodges servants as they rush past, roll up t hurriedly pack household items, etc. Soldiers carry heavy out, moving with a sense of urgency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door is ajar. Don Luiz steps into the study, which ha cleared out quickly. Shelves emptied, drawers left open. scattered about. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A balcony opens off the room. Looking out over the square darkly handsome man with the eyes of a snake. He wears an understated military uniform, and stands utterly still. T RAFAEL MONTERO, Viceroy of Alta California.

dialogues.speaker: DON LUIZ
dialogues.text: I hoped it wasn't true. You're returning to Spain ..?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the Spanish Viceroy, after all - - and California is no longer part of Spain. (bitter) Santa Anna's troops are already on their way to take control of the presidio.]

dialogues.speaker: DON LUIZ
dialogues.text: [The Dons are worried.] How will we fare under Mexico? Ruled by peasants

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: Who will squander this land the same way Spain has. California is richer than anyone can imagine (smiles) Anyone but me. One day, Don Luiz, I will return. And all of our plans will see fruition.

dialogues.speaker: DON LUIZ
dialogues.text: Know that we will always remain loyal to you. And will strive to keep California at least ... a little civilized.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: A hard thing, in this land of savages. He catches the eye of the firing SQUAD LEADER.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Begin the execution! +IN THE SQUARE: Alejandro and Joaquin scramble across a r Below them, the Squad Leader draws his sword.

dialogues.speaker: SQUAD LEADER
dialogues.text: Preparén! (he raises his sword) Apuntén! The crowd is still. Alejandro and Joaquin search for Zorr prisoners stand straight, meeting death with honor. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Squad Leader is about to slash his arm down --

dialogues.speaker: SQUAD LEADER
dialogues.text: Disparen! Fingers tighten on triggers -- ?with a CRACK the fall of a whip wraps around one of the barrels -- and yanks it sideways, into the next, sending sideways, and so on, like dominoes, so that all the rifle pointed at the SQUAD LEADER --

dialogues.speaker: SQUAD LEADER
dialogues.text: No disparen! No disparen -- Too late -- the soldiers FIRE. The Squad Leader crumples The whip-wielder leaps nimbly into the square: an apparit black, sword drawn. Alejandro spots him first --

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: Zorro! The crowd sees him. People point; a cry rises up:

dialogues.speaker: EL ZORRO
dialogues.text: Zorro reaches the prisoners. Three quick slashes free the Several of the soldiers reload. Others draw their swords, Zorro -- Zorro fights with graceful economy, anticipating all atta [As the freed prisoners make their escape, Felipe upends barrels.] The barrels roll free, blocking and tripping so The CROWD has erupted; some of the peasants try to block soldiers, who club them down -- Zorro parries two soldiers' swords into a wheel of the ov wagon, spins the wheel; their swords are wrenched away.

dialogues.speaker: DON LUIZ
dialogues.text: Trust Zorro to spoil a good execution.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: I was counting on it. He takes a candle from a sconce, light a torch strapped t balcony rail. The torch FLARES to life -- ON ALEJANDRO AND JOAQUIN, as they look up, see the signal (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ?-- as do several SOLDIERS, who emerge onto the wood balc below the boys, taking up positions to fire at Zorro.

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: Look!

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: An ambush! We’ve got to warn Zorro - Alejandro is ahead of him. There's a large, loose brick o roof's edge. He strains to shove it off. Joaquin joins hi The stone SMASHES down on the soldiers, taking them out. Zorro turns at the noise, sees the soldiers -- then spots Other soldiers start firing at him. Zorro dives away, SMA through the door of a building -- Alejandro and Joaquin peer over the roof's edge. Like the they wait for Zorro to reappear -- Black-gloved hands drop onto their shoulders. They spin - It is Zorro. He has almost magically appeared behind them

dialogues.speaker: ZORRO
dialogues.text: My thanks to you, gentlemen. He removes a MEDALLION from around his neck. It has an in design: several circles within the large circle, with var of radii intersecting.

dialogues.speaker: ZORRO
dialogues.text: Here. A symbol of my gratitude. But you’1l have to share it. He holds it. It's a ceremonious moment. The Medallion gle Alejandro reaches for it, but too late -- Joaquin takes i

dialogues.speaker: ZORRO
dialogues.text: Now -- if you’1l excuse me And he steps off the roof, onto an overhang, leaps to a c onto -- MONTERO'S BALCONY. Zorro holds his blade on Montero, who flinch. Behind him, Don Luiz fades back, fingering his ow

dialogues.speaker: ZORRO
dialogues.text: You were willing to kill those men to trap me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: I'd have killed a hundred men -- if I could be sure that one of them was you.

dialogues.speaker: ZORRO
dialogues.text: You should have learned by now. No innocent will die as long as I'm alive to rescue them. Three men. Three cuts. Lightning-quick, he makes THREE QUICK CUTS on Montero's n Montero slaps a hand up, covering them.

dialogues.speaker: ZORRO
dialogues.text: A souvenir of your days in California. (beat ) Good-bye, Montero. And good riddance. He whistles -- ?A HUGE BLACK STALLION gallops into the square. Zorro lea from the balcony onto its back. Soldiers scramble as Zorr through them, up a flight of exterior stairs -- Silhouetted against the setting sun low on the horizon, Z horseback leaps from rooftop to rooftop, then is gone. ON ALEJANDRO AND JOAQUIN, watch in awe as he disappears. feeling of ceremony, Joaquin lifts the medallion, drapes his neck. Alejandro reaches out to touch it, lightly, rev ON THE BALCONY OVERLOOKING THE SQUARE. Montero lowers his his neck. On the palm is the bloody IMPRINT of a backward mirroring the one on his neck. Montero clenches his hand into a bloody fist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A waterfall cascades over stone. Zorro rides up, dismount smoothly. Removes the horse's tack and saddle, pets him.

dialogues.speaker: ZORRO
dialogues.text: There you go, Tornado. Take the rest of the night off. Tornado snorts, gallops away. Saddle over his shoulder, Z climbs a path, disappears behind the waterfall --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large GRANDFATHER CLOCK swings aside on oiled hinges. I secret doorway, cave wall visible beyond. DIEGO DE LA VEG out. Mid-thirties, a dashing and handsome man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diego steps in quietly. A striking view through the windo cliffs above the moonlit ocean. A large stand of manzanit outside. But Diego's eyes are on the small occupant of a beneath the window sill--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, darling Elena. Do you want to hear what your father did tonight? It is quite the hair-raising adventure -- J In the crib is ELENA DE LA VEGA, almost two. A sleeping a with funny-looking spiky hair. Diego dotes on her

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: (re: her hair) Oh, you've heard it already?

dialogues.speaker: ESPERANZA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She doesn't understand a word you say. She just likes the sound of your voice. [Standing in the doorway is ESPERANZA. She wears a simple accented by a yellow pafuelo -- a full-length silk scarf. grows up to resemble her mother at all (and she will), sh break a thousand hearts. Diego slips an arm around Espera waist.

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: Someday she'll listen to my stories that's all I ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exposed oak beams. Elegant furniture and filled bookshelv by candlelight. Diego and Elena enter.

dialogues.speaker: ESPERANZA
dialogues.text: All I ask is you be around to tell them. More fear is in her tone than she intended. Diego notes i

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: Esperanza ... She gestures ‘one moment.' Shuts her eyes, gathering hers looks at Diego, in control of her fear now.

dialogues.speaker: ESPERANZA
dialogues.text: Diego ... I love you ... and I love you for what you do. But ... I can smell the gunsmoke on you. (wryly) And you're not getting any younger -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: (pulls her close) I assure you ... My bones aren't brittle yet.

dialogues.speaker: ESPERANZA
dialogues.text: Not all of them, anyway. A passionate kiss -- [] Suddenly the door CRASHES open, a full weight behind it. Other SOLDIERS spill in behind him

dialogues.speaker: ESPERANZA
dialogues.text: Madre de Dios -- Montero strides in. A blood-stained bandage is around his

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: Viceroy -- this is my home. what do you want here? (re: the bandage) Did you cut yourself shaving? MONTERO. Glib as ever, de la Vega. I have come to settle things between us.

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: There is nothing between us.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: You are a betrayer, de la Vega. You have stood against me -- and your fellow Dons -- for as long as I can remember.

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: Only when you were wrong. Which has been as long as I can remember.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: You've secretly funded General Santa Anna and his craven rebels -- Don't deny it! Montero regards Diego coldly.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have many powerful friends, in Spain as well as Mexico. But none will seek revenge for the death of Zorro. Esperanza and Diego stare at him. And then -- they laugh. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ESPERANZA
dialogues.text: Believe me, Rafaél -- if he were Zorro, I'd be the first to know.

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: No, actually, I would -- Montero stares at Esperanza. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: You chose badly, Esperanza. You gave your love to the wrong man. Her eyes blaze. She returns his gaze levelly.

dialogues.speaker: ESPERANZA
dialogues.text: There was never any choice to make. Diego steps between them. Glares at Montero.

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: I think you're dizzy, Montero. From loss of blood, perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: For fifteen years Zorro has been a thorn in my side. I've always suspected you, de la Vega. I just never had any proof. From beneath his jacket he produces a black cape and mask imitations of Zorro's. Holds them up to a SERGEANT.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: Find these somewhere. (nods his head) And kill him. A soldier grabs for Diego. Diego evades him, slides the s the soldier's belt. SLAMS the soldier hard into a wall.

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: Now, you choose, Montero: Leave my house. Or ... (a deadly smile) Actually, there's no choice there, either.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: Everyone knows that Diego de la Vega has no affection for the fight. He attacks, engaging Diego -- who is, of course, Zorro. M smiles at Diego's skill. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: You really are Zorro, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: Affection and ability are two different things. This time Diego attacks, forcing Montero back. A soldier, sword drawn, moves to attack Diego's back -- Esperanza grabs a broom and trips him. The Sergeant is dr pistol; Esperanza shoves the bristles into his face, knoc back, then smacks the pistol away. A second soldier moves toward Diego and Montero, who cont duel, blades FLASHING in candlelight. A third soldier moves toward Diego -- ?The Sergeant finds his lost pistol, takes aim at Diego - ?Esperanza leaps to defend Diego from the third soldier - ?The Sergeant FIRES -- The SHOT freezes the room. The next sound is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diego and Montero watch in horror as she crumples to the The Sergeant, aghast, still holds the smoking pistol. As one, Diego and Montero lunge, their blades piercing th Sergeant's heart. The Sergeant falls back against a stand candelabra. It topples, setting curtains ABLAZE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diego drops his sword, leaps to Esperanza. He cradles her arms, her blood staining his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: Oh, Esperanza ... Esperanza ... Montero moves closer, stands over him, staring down in ho Esperanza. He is genuinely stricken, oblivious to the fla growing around them.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: (soft; to himself) You deserved better. You would have loved to see Spain. A BURNING BEAM CRASHES down, separating the two men. Dieg himself back as FLAMES ERUPT HIGHER --

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: Elena! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He scrambles toward her room. WOOD CREAKS -- ?-- Diego turns as a section of WALL FALLS INWARD. He thr his arms in defense --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diego lands hard; he comes to slowly. Firelight illumines He raises his hands -- they are chained. He is in a cage wagon, with several other prisoners. His eyes focus, and -- through the bars he sees his hacienda ENGULFED IN FLAM

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: Elena! ELENA!

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: She's still inside. Diego snaps a look at him, his rage building. He rattles bars, lets loose an almost animal howl --

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: Montero! DAMN YOU TO HELL, MONTERO! I will find you and kill you -- The Soldier RINGS his sword off the bars.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Shut up. The Viceroy didn't get out either. (to the driver) Take him away! You'll rot in the dungeons at Talamantes, de la Vega. You'll die there. The wagon starts forward with a jerk. Diego stares at the HACIENDA. He collapses back, draws his knees up to his ch defeated. Rain begins to fall.

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: I... am dead all ready. (a whisper) Esperanza ... Elena The Soldier watches the wagon disappear. From the Hacienda comes the sound of the ROOF COLLAPSING.

dialogues.speaker: SHOUTS --
dialogues.text: A FIGURE appears, runs OUT OF THE FLAMES. Cloaked in a sm carpet. Soldiers gather round him -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The figure throws back the carpet from his face, leaves i around him like a cape. It is MONTERO.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Viceroy! You're all right -- ?

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: Where's de la Vega?

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Gone -- to Talamantes. With the others. Montero is livid. This is not what he intended.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: No! Get him back here! I'll kill him -- A SCOUT steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: SCOUT
dialogues.text: No time, sir. There are Mexican troops just over the hills. They'll see the fire --

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: Damn! Montero stares in the direction Diego's wagon went. Consi course of action.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: Damn him. Let's go. There comes the soft sound of a BABY CRYING. Montero thro carpet all the way off -- In his arms is ELENA. He cradles her, protecting her from

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: Shh, nifia. Shh. I'll take care of you. (pulls her close) You should have been mine, and now you are. The rain POURS down, extinguishing the FLAMES of the burn hacienda. Smoke pours across the huge, full moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: THE MEDALLION. Hanging from the neck of JOAQUIN twenty years older. Intense, earnest -- and in trouble. A around his neck is a ROPE, tying him to -- -- ALEJANDRO MURIETTA, trailing behind. Handsome despite unkempt hair and shaggy beard. Their hands apparently tie them, they are prisoners of -- THREE-FINGERED JACK, a powerfully-built man, the rough lo bounty hunter. Only three fingers on his left hand; the b the other two jut from his hat band. On horseback, he lea brothers by the rope. They crest a hill. In the distance is a WATERING STATION produce shack with a horse trough and feed bins. Jack grins, gives the rope a yank. Alejandro and Joaquin defeated glance, trudge forward --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: A POSTER: 'WANTED: THE MURIETTA BROTHERS.' Pass drawings of Joaquin and Alejandro. The poster is being nailed to a post by CORPORAL LOPEZ, a soldier. He is watched by the OWNER, his little GIRL, an and a FARMER. Three SOLDIERS loiter, guarding a horse-drawn wagon. Thei drink, and the soldiers help themselves to produce -- to disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The army should be capturing these bandits -- instead of just nailing up wanted posters. People have been disappearing --] (worried) I haven't seen Jose Gonzales in weeks.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: He's right. There are more and more disaparecidos all the time. Farmers Indians -- even woman and children. No one's safe.

dialogues.speaker: LOPEZ
dialogues.text: (shrugs) A few peasants disappear, what does it matter? These Muriettas actually dare to rob cabelleros and soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: The only ones with any money. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zorro could capture them. Zorro could find the disappeared ones].

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Who's Zorro? Lopez rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LOPEZ
dialogues.text: You peasants. Have to have your little stories about Zorro. He picks up a tomato lazily, bites into it.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: (to the girl) Zorro was a great man -- a champion. He protected us. He would stop the disappearances, if he were here.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: He would make people pay for the food they ate. Lopez backhands him -- suddenly and violently.

dialogues.speaker: LOPEZ
dialogues.text: These are taxes. To pay the soldiers who do protect you. He kneels beside the Girl, addresses her like a kindly un

dialogues.speaker: LOPEZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll tell you who Zorro was. Zorro was a crazy man who wore a mask. Do you know what that makes him? A bandit. And if he showed himself around here, we'd treat him just like any other bandit. (a tomato-red smile) We'd hunt him down and kill him.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: Or get someone to do it for you. He points. Everyone looks where he's pointing: At JACK, l ALEJANDRO and JOAQUIN, coming up the road. The soldiers raise their rifles warily. Lopez gestures fo wait as Jack draws near.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I heard soldiers came through here every week. I think I got some people you want to meet. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: (looking at the poster) It's them! It's the Murietta brothers. Lopez examines the brothers. Squints at the poster. Jack dismounts, crowds forward, everyone trying to see the pos

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: So -- how much is the reward? (Lopez glares at him) Just asking.

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: (boastful) Well, these soldiers are delivering the army payroll. That sounds about right.

dialogues.speaker: LOPEZ
dialogues.text: Ha. The reward's two hundred pesos.

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: (aghast ) Two hundred pesos? For each of us? Joaquin reaches up, tears down the poster, looks at it

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: For both of us!

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: That's insulting! (to Jack) If I were you, I wouldn't accept it. You worked too hard to catch us. Lopez's eyes widen -- he finally notices that Joaquin's h free, holding the poster. He points --

dialogues.speaker: LOPEZ
dialogues.text: Hey -- you're not tied up! A 'click' -- Lopez is looking down the barrel of Jack's p freezes. But the soldiers are startled into action. Two r Jack -- Alejandro steps to one side, drops to his knees --

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: Joaquin! Down! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Joaquin drops to his knees. The rope between them is taut Alejandro keeps a grip on the rope, leaving some slack ar neck -- but Joaquin doesn't. He is choked, yanked over as soldiers trip over the rope. Alejandro slips the rope off his neck, jumps the two down soldiers, subdues them -- The third soldier takes aim at Alejandro. Joaquin draws a an old, tarnished spadroon -- from where it was hidden in bedroll. He dives, knocks the rifle aside as the soldier shot going wide. The soldier attacks Joaquin with his bayonet -- and disar easily. His sword goes flying.

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: Hey! Joaquin grabs the rifle barrel, and yanks it away -- then like a bat, clocking the soldier. It's over in seconds, and Lopez is still staring down Jac barrel. The onlookers are a little stunned by it all.

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: (rubbing his throat) Damn it, Alejandro -- next time, warn me. [Alejandro doesn't look up. He's too busy going through t unconscious soldiers' pockets. ]

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: Next time. Jack, gun still on Lopez, picks up the Wanted Poster.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Look at this. I'm not on here. (to Lopez) I'm Three-Fingered Jack. How hard is it to remember that? (holds up his hand) Three fingers! See? Three-Fingered Jack! [Now Alejandro's loading food into a basket as he makes t turn their pockets inside-out. He's not impressed. ]

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: Maybe you shouldn't make an issue of it, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'm a member of this gang. I want a little respect. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Old Man brings Joaquin his sword. Joaquin takes it, m swipes.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Are you supposed to be Zorro?

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: (flattered) You think I look like Zorro?

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: No. [Joaquin deflates. Alejandro chuckles, tosses the basket into the wagon, climbs on.]

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Zorro wasn't a bandit. He just used to wear a medallion like yours, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: Go away. He climbs up on the wagon beside Alejandro.

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let's get out of here. He tries to ignore Alejandro's grin. Alejandro flicks the The wagon moves.

dialogues.speaker: LOPEZ
dialogues.text: Captain Love will have your heads for this. Jack still has his gun on Lopez. He raises his hand -- Lo back -- but Jack just displays his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Remember: Three-Fingered Jack.

dialogues.speaker: LOPEZ
dialogues.text: I'll remember. He mounts his horse, smiles 'thank you.' Waves daintily, horse. Follows the wagon away, leaving behind unconscious excited onlookers, and an angry Lopez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wagon, driverless, horseless, careens down the hillsi into the ravine. ?Jack, wielding a pry bar, SNAPS OPEN a strongbox lock. ?Joaquin strips off the lock, throws back the lid -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The box is filled with GOLD INGOTS. The outlaws gasp. ?Alejandro lifts one out. Turns it in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: We're rich. (to Joaquin) We can keep it, right?

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: Half. Half we give to the mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't start that! What've they ever done for us?

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: Fray Felipe raised us -- taught us --

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: And we turned out so well. That gold is ours! We should just take it and run!

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: Dammit, Alejandro --]

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: This isn't some army payroll. This is something else -- something big. They'll hunt us down. We'll just be three more disaparecidos.

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: Zorro would never have run away --

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: Look around, Joaquin! Do any of us look like Zorro? (pointed) No! Joaquin regards him. Then puts a hand on his shoulder

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: So we ride to the mission. In honor of Zorro. Alejandro looks at him; the point is settled. Alejandro t bar of gold in his hands; sunlight FLARES off of it --  20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slashes of light shine down through the deck. SWORDS CRAS ?Two figures duel with classic small swords. One is an OL SALT, gray and grizzled but still spry. The other one is with long hair, tied back. They duel amongst the boxes of cargo. The Old Salt feints lunges -- and FREEZES. His opponent's blade is aimed dire his heart. He looks up at -- ELENA. Even wearing man's clothes she is breathtaking. Th Salt knocks her blade away, snorts in self-disgust.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SALT
dialogues.text: You got a knack for the blade, girl.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA
dialogues.text: My father is an expert swordsman.

dialogues.speaker: OLD SALT
dialogues.text: Then how come you go to old sailors for your lessons. Old sailors ... and Spanish Gypsies. (her surprise confirms it) Thought I knew the style.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA
dialogues.text: My father would say ... it is improper for a lady to learn the sword. He is a very proper man. (sighs; troubled) And I don't think I'm the proper daughter he deserves. Suddenly the hatch opens; light floods in.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Elena! Elena and Old Salt exchange shocked glances.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I can't imagine what she'd be doing in the hold.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Neither can I -- but I can't find her anywhere else. [Elena makes a decision. Tosses the Old Salt her sword, g traveling cloak -- and wriggles out through a porthole. ] The Old Salt strikes a nonchalant pose -- realizes he sti the swords. He stashes them, reassumes his pose -- just i the CAPTAIN finds him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: We are looking for Don Montero's daughter. Have you seen her?

dialogues.speaker: OLD SALT
dialogues.text: Down here? Not unless she's got a taste for rats. Montero looks in distastefully from the top of the stairw

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: Hardly. She is a refined and delicate lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [Montero, the Captain and the Old Salt emerge from the ho Old Salt spots Elena, climbing over the seaward rail. She him with her eyes. He turns so that the Captain and Monte are to her.]

dialogues.speaker: OLD SALT
dialogues.text: I don't want to be a Jonah -- but could she have...? (jerks his head overboard)

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: (to the Captain) If she has fallen overboard, I will hold you and your crew responsible --

dialogues.speaker: ELENA
dialogues.text: Who's fallen overboard, father? They turn. Elena stands there, the traveling cloak concea attire.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: I was afraid you had --

dialogues.speaker: ELENA
dialogues.text: You were looking for me? Why? Something exciting, I hope. He smiles at her enthusiasm. He offers her his arm.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: Something you've never seen before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montero and Elena are at the rail, his hands over her eye (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: California. He uncovers her eyes. Elena gasps. Across the white-cappe the golden hills move past.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA
dialogues.text: We're there?

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: Our new home. She hugs Montero, her eyes still taking in the sight.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA
dialogues.text: All my life, it seems, I've dreamed of California.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: Don Montero ... your boat is ready. But I tell you again ... this delay will put the tides against us.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: No matter. I must go ashore.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA
dialogues.text: Why, Father? What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: Nothing, dear. Nothing that need concern you. Montero looks away, out across the water, lost in thought

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TORCH blazes. Montero carries it, trailed by the Warden several guards. The cell block is all wet stone and rusted iron bars. Nar of sunlight are swallowed by the oppressive darkness.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: His name is Diego de la Vega. He must be here.

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir, but we don't keep records. Prisoners have no need for names. And only the dead leave Talamantes. Montero shoves the torch between the bars of a cell. Only we see the prisoner inside, blinking painfully at the lig not Diego. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Montero moves to the next cell: not Diego. The next: Not The next. The next A prisoner lies on the ground, unmoving. Eyes staring. Fl buzzing -- he's dead. And he's not Diego. Montero moves o

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Get a coffin. Bury him. [One of the Guards -- ORDAZ -- unlocks the cell door. The stay with Montero and the warden. ] Montero moves faster, checking one cell after another, on after another, recognizing none of them. In one cell, a prisoner sits huddled in the shadows. Mont the torch in -- CLOSE ON: THE PRISONER'S EYES. Reflecting the torch light It is DIEGO. Twenty years older, Diego has been ravaged b Bearded, gray hair, face heavily lined -- none from laugh leg is manacled, the chain bolted into the wall. Montero peers at him. No recognition. He moves on, throwi cell back into darkness. But Diego has recognized Montero. He steps out of the sha staring after him. Diego watches Montero continue down the block, the Warden other two guards trailing.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: You must be right, Warden. He must be dead Diego grabs the bars, rattles them in anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper) He's alive ...] A SCRAPE from down the hall. Diego sees: +ORDAZ, dragging a rough wooden coffin to the dead man's cell. Diego's eyes narrow --

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: Guard! His voice is just a raw croak. Ordaz looks up.

dialogues.speaker: ORDAZ
dialogues.text: I thought you were dumb. Diego motions him closer. Ordaz moves warily. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ORDAZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I been here ten years. What's so important, you have to talk now?

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: (still hoarse) The man that man is looking for I know who he is.

dialogues.speaker: ORDAZ
dialogues.text: who?

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) You'll get a reward. I want some, too. Better food. More of it. Ordaz thinks it over.

dialogues.speaker: ORDAZ
dialogues.text: If it's worth something to Don Montero, it'll be worth something to you. Diego nods reluctantly. Ordaz checks for listeners, moves the bars. Lowers his voice.

dialogues.speaker: ORDAZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: Me. He whips the rope belt from his pants, loops it around th neck, yanks his head into the bars with a CLANG. Ordaz fi Diego CLANGS him again. And again. Ordaz slumps, unconscious. Diego grabs Ordaz's key ring, his cell door, drags the Guard inside. He smiles as he tries one of the keys on his manacle. It work. He tries anther. No good. Then another, and another more frantically -- None of the keys fit. Crushed, Diego drops the key ring. He searches Ordaz. Finds a dagger his boot, tries to fidd lock with it, digs at the ring in the wall -- useless. Diego feels defeated. Then his gaze falls on -- ?-- Ordaz's POWDER HORN. Diego pours black powder into the manacle's keyhole. Pack the dagger. Uses a strip of Ordaz's tunic as wadding. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He wraps more of the tunic around his manacled foot to pr A pouch on Ordaz's belt holds shot and flints. Diego stri the flints against the dagger. The wadding smolders. Diego blows it to life. The makeshi burns quickly. Diego hauls Ordaz's body between him and t as a shield -- THE POWDER EXPLODES with a flash, blowing open the manacl Diego strips the now-BURNING wrap off his foot, teeth gri screaming a silent scream. His foot is blackened and bloo the toes are all still there. He wriggles them thankfully A large chunk of metal juts from Ordaz's chest. Diego sho aside without remorse. He stands. Winces at the pain from foot. Looks down at Ordaz's. At his BOOTS.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 23
dialogues.text: The two other Guards, with a BURIAL DETAIL of four prison into the dead man's cell. The coffin lies there, shut tig body.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND GUARD
dialogues.text: Where's Ordaz?

dialogues.speaker: THIRD GUARD
dialogues.text: Who cares? You four -- haul that out of here. The prisoners move to lift the coffin -- ?It_is heavy. They struggle. The Prison Guard snaps a fla

dialogues.speaker: THIRD GUARD
dialogues.text: Put your backs into it! They haul the coffin up, and carry it through the door, i corridor. They carry it past -- DIEGO'S CELL. Where a prisoner huddles in the shadows. OR dead guard. His feet are bare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prisoners, sweaty with exertion, lower the coffin int freshly-dug shallow grave. They spade dirt in on top of i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The graveyard. The white crosses glow in the light of the The fresh grave. There is the sound of wood SPLINTERING. SHIFTS. Moves. CAVES IN -- Diego's hand, clutching the dagger, shoves out the dirt. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Diego hauls himself out of the coffin, out of the earth. for air; draws deep, cleansing breaths. He looks back int coffin, at the body. Crosses himself. He rises. His leg buckles. Diego grabs one of the wooden Uses it as a crutch, he limps from the graveyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rocky cove, spectacular in the moonlight. A campfire bu short of the treeline. Joaquin and Alejandro lay on bedro Three-Fingered Jack stands watch.

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: ... I've always wanted a horse. A black one. And a silver trimmed saddle and silver stirrups. People will see me and say, ‘There, that must be a great man.' Three-Fingered Jack leaves his post, comes toward the fir

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I know what I'm going to do with my share. I'm going to 'Frisco. I'll sip amontillado, buy the most beautiful women, and smoke cigarettes. How 'bout you, Alejandro?

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: I couldn't hope to match the grandeur of your dreams.

dialogues.speaker: JOAQUIN
dialogues.text: Oh, come on. Tell us again about the Magnificent hacienda, the love of a sweet, dark-eyed sefiorita who calls you Don Alejandro

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: You keep your horse, Joaquin. I'll keep my sefiorita -- There is a CRACK from the darkness. The three freeze, and Alejandro dives for his gun -- -- but stops short, a BAYONET in his face, freezing him. stands over him. The camp is quickly circled by soldiers, some with lanter horses, all with guns leveled. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A man on a superb buckskin horse looms out of the darknes HARRISON LOVE. His posture is perfect, his gaze intense. scar on his left cheek. He wears a small sword; a saber h scabbard from his saddle. First, last and always, he is a He has a Texas accent. Love gazes down imperiously, a wanted poster in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: LOVE
dialogues.text: So. The infamous Murietta Bandits. (nods to Jack) And you must be Three-Fingered Jack. He displays the poster. It's a new one, with three drawin Joaquin, Alejandro ... and a three-fingered hand. Jack sl hand behind his back.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Maybe ... maybe not.

dialogues.speaker: LOVE
dialogues.text: I am Captain Harrison Love, of the First Dragoons of California. And you are my prisoners. (mocking) Truth to tell, I expected more of a fight.

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: If you insist. Alejandro kicks away the rifle pointed at him. Grabs two logs and virtually throws the campfire at the soldiers. S

dialogues.speaker: FIRED --
dialogues.text: Soldiers scatter as Love's horse rears back. Jack grabs h SHOOTS a soldier. Joaquin dives for his sword. He runs a through -- A soldier reloads his breech-loader from a cartridge pouc Alejandro shoves a burning log at the pouch, IGNITING it. the soldier into two others -- ?The cartridges EXPLODE, taking all three out --

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: Scatter! He grabs one of the soldiers' swords. The outlaws run. SH follow them --

dialogues.speaker: LOVE
dialogues.text: You two -- secure the strongbox! The rest -- after them! He spurs his horse after Joaquin, the soldiers following  28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON ALEJANDRO: who heads uphill. He breaks into a clearing ARMED SOLDIER turns and sees him. Alejandro brandishes his sword with a flourish. ?The Armed Soldier grins, pulls his pistol. ?Alejandro looks distressed at the sight of the gun. He f raising his sword as the SHOT is FIRED -- The SOUND of bullet hitting steel. Alejandro looks: his s broken. But he is okay. He grins -- Now the Armed Soldier looks distressed. He tries to re-lo pistol -- Alejandro hurls the sword hilt at him, hitting head. He grabs the soldier's LANTERN, takes off. A RIDER and a SOLDIER on foot turn and look: Alejandro's bobs in and among the trees. They follow. +0N JOAQUIN: running down a rock-covered slope into a spi moonlight. One soldier brac rifle on a piece of driftwood. FIRES -- ?Jack crumples, shot in the leg. Soldiers converge. ON ALEJANDRO: who comes to the edge of a steep hill. He s Joaquin below on the rocky slope. Sounds of pursuit near. The Rider gestures; they split up. The Soldier creeps tow bobbing LANTERN. He steps around a tree, pistol leveled. The LANTERN hangs from a bobbing tree branch.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: It's a damned trick -- He turns -- too late; Alejandro hits him hard, knocks him Grabs the pistol and rifle, extinguishes the lantern. ON JOAQUIN: pinned by rifle fire. One soldier moves close has a clear shot at Joaquin. He draws a bead -- ?-- and a SHOT kills him -- ON ALEJANDRO: who looks up from the sights of his stolen smiles. ON JOAQUIN: as another soldier charges forward, bayonet a Joaquin parries the thrust -- but the bayonet impales him thigh. He cries out, clubs the man down. Love reins up. ?Joaquin stands there, sword drawn, waiting. ?Love smiles. Draws the heavy saber from its scabbard. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ?Joaquin doesn't like the looks of this. He dodges left, his leg betrays him -- ?Love's horse sidesteps in half-pass, cutting him off. ?Joaquin tries again -- ?Love backs the horse up, its body blocking Joaquin off. playing with him, a cat with a mouse. Love swings his saber at Joaquin, who barely parries in t heavy blade knocking him off-balance. He falls backward. Love advances. The horse rears, draws its front legs in - levade. It kicks out with its front legs, smashes Joaquin from his grasp. It lands in the deadfall, out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: LOVE
dialogues.text: You are not worthy of that blade, Murietta. Love's face gives no hope of mercy. Joaquin gambles: he f then dives, rolls beneath the horse, comes up on the othe Love's buckskin pirouettes, the spin giving impetus to Lo slicing through the air, toward Joaquin's neck -- -- and suddenly THE MEDALLION IS SAILING FREE. ?It lands in a crevice, stained by Joaquin's blood. ON ALEJANDRO: his eyes wide in shock.

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: Joaquin! JOAQUIN! Furious, he breaks from his hiding place, toward Love --

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: Damn you, you bastard! DAMN YOU! He FIRES the pistol -- ?Love doesn't flinch. The bullet barely misses him, hits behind him. He draws a handkerchief from his sleeve, wipe blade, his eyes never leaving Alejandro.

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: I'll kill you! Several mounted soldiers join Love. Jack, still alive, is over the saddle of one. Alejandro pulls up short. ?The soldiers take aim -- Alejandro leaps for the Rider who was hunting him, knocks his horse. Swings across the saddle in a trick-riding mou reins the horse around, stares down at Love.

dialogues.speaker: ALEJANDRO
dialogues.text: I will see you dead, Love! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: RIFLE FIRE tears up the tree beside Alejandro. He wheels disappears into the woods. ON LOVE: as he gestures for his soldiers to pursue.

dialogues.speaker: LOVE
dialogues.text: Go, capture him. (to one soldier) You -- bring this one's body. (sharp) And take special care with the head!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montero's ship lies at anchor. Longboats row toward shore beach is undeveloped -- no buildings or docks -- but full activity: VAQUEROS stack cured cattle hides. Trappers, tr out their wares. A small knot of CABALLEROS wait, away from the others. Th powerful dons, dressed in their silver-trimmed finery. The first longboat hits the beach. Montero steps out of i LUIZ, elderly now, one eye milky with cataracts steps for carries a dark wood alcalde's cane.

dialogues.speaker: DON LUIZ
dialogues.text: (loudly) The Viceroy is returned! Some cheers from the gathering people on the beach, and a frowns. But the cabelleros applaud, step forward. Among t HECTOR, who resembles a bulldog. DON AGUILAR, a bow-legge

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: Welcome back to California, Don Montero.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: Don Hector ... It's been a long time Don Aguilar ... Don Ramon (smiles warmly) Luiz.

dialogues.speaker: DON LUIZ
dialogues.text: Rafaél. They embrace.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: You look comfortable holding the alcalde's cane, Don Luiz. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Don Luiz regards the silver-handled cane in his hand. It distinctive -- polished, but still retaining the natural curves of the wood.

dialogues.speaker: DON LUIZ
dialogues.text: The alcalde's job is difficult -- but it does seem to suit me

dialogues.speaker: BYSTANDER
dialogues.text: (a little too loudly) Ha -- the alcalde's as crooked as his cane! Don Luiz spots him, raises his cane angrily --

dialogues.speaker: DON LUIZ
dialogues.text: How dare you --

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: Wait, Don Luiz. (to the Bystander) You're unhappy with the way you're being governed? The Bystander screws up his courage -- and tells the trut

dialogues.speaker: BYSTANDER
dialogues.text: . Yes. Montero turns, addresses a TRADER, drawing in listeners.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: And you -- you feel ill-served by your government? Neglected?

dialogues.speaker: TRADER
dialogues.text: Except at tax time.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: (laughs) Of course. Tell me, Don Luiz -- are you carrying out the edicts of Mexico?

dialogues.speaker: LUIZ
dialogues.text: As best I can -- Montero plays to the crowd, an impromptu stump speech.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: That's the problem! You are being ruled by a government in absentia. You have no representation. No voice in your own futures There are nods, murmurs of agreement. One man is not smil pushes through the crowd -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO.
dialogues.text: He stares fiercely at Montero, murder in his eyes. He mov the front. He still uses his make-shift cane.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's what led to the formation of the Republic of Texas! The Republic of New Mexico! Perhaps it is time for Californios to take the reins of the destiny of California! The crowd begins to buzz about the idea. With a smile, Mo moves on, surrounded by the dons.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: It's a heady idea, isn't it? An independent California ...

dialogues.speaker: DON LUIZ
dialogues.text: Was General Santa Anna willing to listen to our proposal?

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: Santa Anna will listen to anything, as long as it ends with the sound of change in his pockets. (it's great news) He has agreed to our proposal. The Dons are happily surprised.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He'll be arriving at the end of the month.

dialogues.speaker: DON LUIZ
dialogues.text: My God ... that's wonderful. Wonderful news.

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: You are a miracle worker, Don Montero. Montero glances down the beach -- Captain Love rides toward them at full gallop. A BURLAP B from his saddle, holding something basketball-sized. Love dismounts even as the horse is slowing. Diego is cut changes course through the crowd, frustrated. Love strides to Montero, grasps his hand. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: Harrison! I was wondering where you were.

dialogues.speaker: LOVE
dialogues.text: Don Montero! Good to see you, sir!

dialogues.speaker: DON LUIZ
dialogues.text: On your recommendation, Captain Love has taken command of the presidio. He has done an excellent job ridding the pueblo of its less desirable elements. ON DIEGO, moving closer. A small motion, and something dr his sleeve into his hand: a DAGGER.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: When you wrote to me of the lawlessness in California, I knew it called for a strong hand. Love rests his hand on the burlap bag hanging from his sa

dialogues.speaker: LOVE
dialogues.text: And a sharp sword. (humbly) In fact, I believe it is safe to say that there is nothing and no one to fear in all of California. ON DIEGO: who nears his target, intent on Montero's back ELENA disembarks from a second long boat. As she moves up beach, a scent catches her attention. She investigates, p bloom from a manzanita bush. Diego draws his arm back, the blade glinting --

dialogues.speaker: ELENA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Father! As one, Diego and Montero turn -- Recognition, shock, fills Diego's face. Smiling, Elena hurries toward them. Diego stares, frozen, as his daughter approaches --

dialogues.speaker: DIEGO
dialogues.text: (a whisper) Dios Mio : -- but then Elena_goes past Diego, to Montero. Diego foll with his eyes, feeling the pain and loss of two decades. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: Gentlemen. Allow me to present my daughter, Elena... Hector bows. Don Luiz's expression betrays him: he's star the claim. But he accepts it, and bows.

dialogues.speaker: DON LUIZ
dialogues.text: I am honored, Sefiorita. Diego watches, his heart breaking. Love takes Elena's hand. Their eyes meet.

dialogues.speaker: LOVE
dialogues.text: Elena -- your beauty is always welcome. Particularly in this barbarous place.

dialogues.speaker: MONTERO
dialogues.text: It would be welcome anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA
dialogues.text: Father, please -- his compliment was flattering enough. But thank you for leaping to my defense. (kisses his cheek) What would I do without you? The dagger drops from Diego's hand. His eyes show realiza cannot kill Montero. He stumbles, fades into the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: ELENA
dialogues.text: Father, what is this flower? It smells very familiar.

dialogues.speaker: LOVE
dialogues.text: That's manzanita. But you must be mistaken about its familiarity. It's native to California. Elena frowns, puzzled. Don Luiz ushers them all up the be

dialogues.speaker: DON LUIZ
dialogues.text: Come with me, Don Montero. I've had your hacienda prepared for your arrival. Love nearly steps on something -- ?The abandoned DAGGER. He picks it up, examines it. Glanc suspiciously into the crowds.

dialogues.text: The site of Joaquin's death. Empty. Quiet. Alejandro appe exhausted. He ties his horse to the deadfall -- and sees sword. Stares at it a long moment. DRIED BLOOD stains the rocks where Joaquin's body lay. Al kneels beside the spot. A FLASH OF LIGHT catches his eye. glints off of something: THE MEDALLION. ?Alejandro picks it up -- and can't hold back his tears. on the rocky slope, he cries, his body hunched in mournin
